My pediatrician was extremely dismissive of my concerns regarding my oldest and would push any medical explanation as far back and as slow as she could. ""They take longer than your average kid, but give it time"" was her mantra. Well, around 8 years old my daughter was diagnosed as severely autistic. She could've used some much earlier intervention, but her doctor assured me ""it's probably just her personality" or ""this is the age when they start acting out, etc.... I was very clear about both sides of the family having autism as well as it being more common in little girls who have an older sibling of the male gender. When I went back to her with my concerns, she somewhat listened, but really doubled down on staking her reputation on my daughter being neurotypical. I found a new pediatrician immediately.

So for many reasons, I find it hard to trust a doctor who is used to having the last word. This doesn't apply to EVERY pediatrician. I did manage to find one who I did trust and who was as direct as she could be with me.

Text_Numeracy: I was with my sister when her water broke.  She was thirty-seven weeks into her pregnancy, so we weren't about to panic, but we still knew this was early.  I knew that we had time to get to the hospital, but we should also get there soon.  As the contractions started to come closer together, we would time them. The hospital was about thirty minutes away.  She had been having mild contractions for about a week, so when we got to the hospital, she was already at a four.  When we left her to be registered and changed into a hospital gown, they were five minutes apart.  By the time they checked her after thirty minutes, she was at an eight.  We were so glad we hadn't waited too long!  At nine and thirty-seven weeks, they would not allow her to eat or drink anything by mouth, so she hadn't had anything since about six that morning. An example is:  my daughter has Phenylketonuria, or PKU for short, and there is a very specific diet that must be followed in order to not develop mental retardation, which is what happens if you do not follow it.  Reason being that PKU is an inability to metabolize the amino acid phenylalanine into the amino acid tyrosine.  So when phenylalanine builds up in the system, it crosses the blood-brain barrier and causes damage to the brain, particularly the part that controls thinking, reasoning and intelligence.  So avoiding high-phenylalanine foods is critical.  When my daughter was younger and in the pediatric pharmacy program here in Salt Lake, she was able to have a phenylalanine level test every week.  They would see how much was in her blood on the day of the test, then give medicines that day to lower it based on the level, and in five days would do another test. I trust her when it comes to physical stuff, which is interesting because when I tell her about mental health stuff, she always tells me I don't need to see a therapist. Well, fuck that noise.

I do have issues with the whole medical approach to everything, though. The fact of the matter is that most doctors only receive a couple of hours of training on nutrition, and the prescribing of psych medications is very influenced by drug companies. And they'll give you something with absolutely no effect, and then when it wears off give you something else even though the first one caused the problem but we don't know that, haha. Psych meds are all held together with the shadow of a hope and nothing tangible.
